field_edited_text.value:
Improvements to Northern Route







possible adverse effect upon abutting properties. In lieu of this
arrangement the Hoffman Street alternate would provide an
elevated structure which for six blocks would be in close proximity
to existing residential structures. The net effect of the Hoffman
Street alternate on the adjacent neighborhood would certainly be
more detrimental than the original plan.

Taking all these factors into consideration it seems clear that
the Hoffman Street alternate is less desirable than the original
plan and should not be adopted. Our conclusions on this score
are not altered by the fact that there is some indication that
adoption of the Hoffman Street alternate might reduce opposition
to the Northern Route.

. Northern Mt. Vernon Alternate

One of the principal objections to the Northern Route has
been based on the quality of the buildings in or adjacent to the
right of way through the Mt. Vernon area. A further objection
has been based on the extent to which the proposed route splits
the Mt. Vernon area in two. It has been suggested that some of
these objections might be overcome if this portion of the Express-
way could be shifted a few blocks to the north where it would be
closer to the northern limits of the Mt. Vernon area and where
existing improvements are somewhat less desirable. Under this
proposal the intersection of the Northern Route and the Jones
Falls Expressway would be moved approximately three blocks
northward so that the crossing would occur at about the point
where Guilford Avenue will cross the Jones Falls Expressway.
From this intersection the Expressway would go directly east on
an elevated structure so as to meet the original route on the other
side of Greenmount Avenue between Preston Street and Hoffman
Street. Proceeding westerly from the Jones Falls Expressway
the proposal would call for the East-West Route to pass over

Mt. Royal Avenue to Calvert Street. It would then turn south-
westerly passing diagonally through the present street pattern to
Cathedral Street. Continuing in the same direction it would join
the original route at about Howard Street. The alignment of this
alternate is indicated by the heavy line on Sheet 22.

While this proposal could be made to work, it has certain

undesirable features:

(a) It would be impossible to depress the Expressway at any
point between Greenmount Avenue and Fremont Ave-
nue. It would thus pass through the center of town as
an elevated structure.

(b) The only type of interchange which could be devised
with the Jones Falls Expressway would be awkward and
cumbersome.

(c) While it is true that the structures in the northern part
of the Mt. Royal area through which this proposed
revision would pass are somewhat lower in quality than
those between Chase and Eager Streets, nevertheless, the
fact that the revised route would pass diagonally through
this section would result in some highly undesirable
taking lines. The scars left by this routing would be
more damaging than those for the 1957 Plan.

For all of these reasons no more detailed consideration was

given to this proposal.

This phase of our study led to the conclusion that no small-scale
improvements of the Northern Route could be made. If the East-West
Expressway is to be located along this route the present alignment seems
to be the best possible. This conclusion is not surprising when it is con-
sidered that the present path is the result of several years of study on the
part of the Planning Commission.
